title: Commander Keen Doom question...
content:
What would make a better Commander Keen Doom mod?

A) A recreation of Commander Keen 4, 5 and/or 6
B) A recreation of Commander Keen 1-3
C) A new story
D) A & B
E) All of the above
F) None of the above

For option A... it is not unreasonable to incorporate all of the levels in Commander Keen 4-6 in a Doom environment. There may be differences in constructing a level in a 3D environment that is supposed to be based in a 2D environment.

I've been leaning toward Option C for the most part.


And for those of you who do not have Doom 2 - when the time comes, I will test this wad with FreeDoom, which is an IWAD based on Doom 2 that uses completely new textures, monsters, weapons, everything, but also allows people to play Doom 2 wads.

title: Re: Commander Keen Doom question...
content:
I'll go with A.

Depending on how this goes, I might also do a B and a C...


While A gives me less freedom of creativity, it also provides more of a structure that I can use to work with. Furthermore, I won't have to really make any more enemies, just alter the existing ones so that they are able to move in 4 or 8 directions instead of 2.

I might even be able to provide a way to leave a cliff-hanger at the end of the game (after playing through a Doom-ized version of Keen 4, 5 and 6) to leave room for a sequel in either the form of another Keen Doom, or a MMF game.

title: Re: Commander Keen Doom question...
content:
It should be no problem constructing all of the levels that appear in Keen 4 - 6...

Keen 4 would have 18 levels - 17 playable levels including the secret level, and the 18th level would be a 3D main map.

Keen 5 would have 15 levels - 14 playable + secret and the 3D main map. I am really looking forward to recreating this episode.

Keen 6 would have 17 levels. This makes for a total of 50 levels.

Doom may be limited to 32 levels, but GZDoom isn't. There are two ways I can include 50 separate levels.

One is keep the total of actual maps to 32, but have some levels paired with another - mainly levels that might have the same theme music. GZDoom allows the possibility for the player to enter a level, exit it, and reenter it as if it never changed. In fact, I can construct each entire episode to act like one gigantic level - and the only thing that will notify you that you are entering a level or leaving a level is probably some text that appears on the screen. A line defined as an exit can be set to take you to and from a main map, as well as make it act more like a silent teleporter. The problem with this is that crossing that line is noticeable, since an entire level still has to load. I don't intend on creating massively complex levels, so it should only take a split second to load for most computers.

The other possibility is to add a Map 33-50... This will also make it easier to use a map-warp, say by typing idclev45 for level 45 since if I were to have Map 15 use two levels, for example, it'd be really hard to warp to one level or the other.A lesson in Ascillan:
